review_body: My husband and I visited in September (temps were 75/65) and stayed a week. We selected this hotel because we needed to be near NYU and most hotels in area were booked up; or $600 ! We booked through Expedia.Main pluses: Bed was comfortable, and the 24/7 front staff friendly and accommodating. Other pluses were adequate lighting, a shower that worked, working safe, subway about 4 blocks away, 3 blocks to Whole Foods.Otherwise it was kind of like visiting with a friend -- a bit grimy and with small things not working (e.g. broken drawer knobs, phone in bedroom). Not "hotel spotless". And it was priced the same as hotels. If you need a suite with kitchen (and are OK with some grubbiness) this would be a good choice.As it happened, we didn't need the kitchen but I checked it out and it seemed to all work; though pots&pans, dishes were few; and serving bowls non-existent. The room is made up and fresh towels supplied every day.It's a noisy neighborhood but we got used to that.We stayed a week but were only in the room for nights and a few afternoon rests. There were just two of us, but you could certainly fit 4 with the extra couple sleeping on the futon/couch in the sitting room.Some minuses that are important to me:In bathroom nowhere to set anything down or hang anything -- it is a big room and we brought in some chairs to serve this need. But why not supply a shelf and some hooks?Bathroom sink was tiny and as I do laundry when I travel that was awkward. Again, plenty of room for something more spacious so why not?There were only 4 hangers so bring your own.There is little space to unpack into so you kind of have to live out of your suitcase. (two 2-drawer nightstands and the top of the closet safe were the only places to unpack into)Some minuses important to my husband:Internet connection via their wireless was intermittentThe TV is poor quality and the channel listing was wrong

My sister, my son and I stayed here. We purposely moved hotels so we could be the other end of Manhattan and grouped our activities to suit. Everything was excellent, from check in to check out - when they arranged a town car to the airport. The housekeeping was more than we expected - but we did leave a tip each day with a thank you note :) Location was brilliant within walking distance to Chinatown, Little Italy and Greenwich Village. The suite gave us room to spread out. I used the laundry which was helpful. There is a Wholefoods just along the street which was great too. Rooms are a little tired, and could do with some attention as far as paintwork etc (looks like there had been some major patching) but it was clean and we thought the price was right!

- The wifi signal was very unstable. Both my Android and iPhone 5 couldn't connect to the wifi. Connecting to my PC and Mac was slow.- The hair dryer is the weakest I've ever seen. If you have long hair, it takes a long long time to dry your hair.- No soft pillows. The pillows were way too high for me. I couldn't sleep well.- There were two windows but no sun light.- Not LGBT friendly.The bottom line: With this price, you can find somewhere better.

This hotel was a great find. For the price I expected a shoebox sized room but they provided a very large 2 BR room suite with a big private bathroom and kitchen. The room was clean and the service superb! The fitness room is small but adequately supplied and the lobby was spacious with strong wifi signal. The hotel is a very easy walk to Little Italy and Chinatown, and 4 blocks or so from Grand subway station.There were some relatively minor drawbacks. The decor is dated. The in room wifi signal was too weak to use. The neighborhood is a bit run down, and there's no insure parking (no surprise in NYC). But these minor things dont change the fact that this is a clean, safe, comfortable, spacious and well-run hotel that is an incredible value.

I'm a travel agent who travelled to New York with a friend and struggled to find options that had two twin beds. I had read some earlier reviews and was a bit concerned but couldn't really fault the place. A bit dated (kitchen )but it really is a reasonably priced alternative to expensive New York hotels. We loved having the extra space of an apartment and the ability to come home (after pounding the streets for hours) and have something to eat before heading out.It could be noisy at night with street cleaners etc as we faced onto the street from the bedroom but nothing too bad.Friends had suggested staying lower Manhatten and I'm so glad we did. The location of Off Soho Suites was just perfect. You can't fault the Location with many good bars, shops and restaurants a short walk away. Whole Foods is just around the corner if you want to eat in.Willie, Gabe and the other gentleman who worked their couldn't have been more friendly or helpful.I will happily recommend it to my clients and friends

This is a bargain. A two room United with kitchen accomodates 4 adults. Decent comfort, good beds, ok kitchen and bath plus a pleasant lounge with wi-fi.No extras but great value and super location if You like to stay in lower Manhattan.

We were a group of four women who visited NYC for fun over 4 days. We very much enjoyed our stay at this hotel. The hotel is close to Chinatown and Little Italy and the walk to two of the subway stations was about 2 blocks. Noise level was good because the hotel is off the main thoroughfare. All three gentlemen who worked there were very helpful and cheerful when we asked any questions. They immediately came up to help us with the fold out bed and everyday, did a great job cleaning our room- our dishes were even washed. One of the ladies used the exercise room and needed the treadmill fixed- the gentleman immediately corrected the situation.  The suite had "character"- there was a window with a fire escape -overlooking a neat alleyway with a replica of the Statue of Liberty. The bathroom was good sized- had shelving which was great for 4 women. The kitchenette had a full size fridge and surprisingly a gas operated stove. There was a microwave to heat up leftovers.  If you are looking for a contemporary facny 5 star hotel, this is not the place. This is a htoel that is like a comfortable slightly worn easy chair- nothing fussy but very welcoming.

A group of us, from the international offices of our organization, were put in this hotel for a global meeting in NYC. First off, their service was not initially very good in the reception. I was told to wait a few minutes to check in and the person at reception left me there for about 20 minutes. I had to go back and remind him I was waiting, and he just gave me the key and let me up. However, they were very nice about receiving my lost suitcase later that week.The room I was put in (luckily) was one of the deluxe, it was a mini apartment, a room with a double bed, bathroom (with tub), kitchenette and sitting room. However, it was a bit dated, and fairly clean, but could have been better. The heating system was a bit old, and it turned on automatically (or so they said), and there were times that it got really cold, and I had no control over the thermostat.I had trouble sleeping the 4 nights I was there, due to this constant noise of driers. One night there was a party in the room next to mine, and I could hear everything.The location is pretty good, it is close to Chinatown, and it’s got a nice neighborhood a few blocks down; and there is a subway station about 1.5 blocks away.

We brought our son to NYC for the first time. This location is a perfect mix of all NYC has to offer.It needs a bit of updating but was clean and quiet. The little kitchen area was perfect for saving money on some meals. WE would go back to this litle gem in an instant.

Myself and a few of my friends from around the US came into NYC for St. Patrick's day weekend. We stayed here on Friday and Saturday night. We were looking for somewhere clean and safe that had ample room for all of us. This was exactly what we were looking for. It isn't luxurious, and doesn't have a ton of flair. But that's not what we were looking for. The staff was very nice and helpful when we needed them to be. The only minor thing that I could ding them for was that the "Sofa Bed" was actually a futon. There was a coffee maker in the room, but unfortunately they did not provide complementary coffee.Stay here with confidence for a clean, safe time in NYC.

You can't do better than this if you want a value location with a kitchen and/or separate bedroom in Manhattan. READ CAREFULLY, not all rooms have private bath. We stayed in the deluxe suite; "sleeps 4" is queen bed in separate bedroom with door, plus fold out couch (comfy) that sleeps 2. Nice large bathroom, kitchen with frig, stove, microwave, coffeemaker, dishes for 4. Baseboard heat with no in-room controls, but was nice and warm. Front desk staff very nice. Not fancy, but clean, safe, stylish updates to make rooms in an old building. FWIW, about $20 cab ride from Penn Station, 2 block walk to F subway line and Whole Foods. We were on 3rd floor, quietest room I have ever had in NYC. Funky neighborhood with lots of character. Felt safe everywhere we walked. Would stay again.

Great for affordable family travel. We stayed in a 2-room suite with kitchen. Much bigger than your average NY hotel room--more like an apartment. It is true that rooms can use some updating and there are no fancy amenities but it's a great location, very clean and desk staff is friendly, super-responsive and helpful. They arranged car service to the airport and that was reasonable and fast as well. We will definitely stay here again.

We had a couple of the deluxe suites for our recent holiday which included adult children. Stayed for a week, tipped housekeeping each day (including weekend), and was very happy with location and service provided. Separate bedroom, comfy sofa bed, decent sized bathroom, kitchen ok. Couldn't resist the nearby Wholefoods for meals and very decent coffee, although for Australians, there were actually a number of great coffee places. Nearby subway station got us to theatres in a short time, but plenty of activities in the area kept us busy there - restaurants, cafes, cinemas, shopping, people watching etc. I would really recommend this hotel if you're happy with a fairly low key place for a lowish key price.

Just blocks away from Soho, East Village, Chinatown, Little Italy... subways all around, very quiet and safe neighborhood, full of cool bars and little restos for a fun night. And The Bowery just around the corner! Our room (or apartment, cause it had a complete kitchen, a cool living room and a huge bathroomm on top of a nice bedroom) was super comfortable. Sunny and clean, staff very friendly. And the price? That made the mix GREAT, super affordable!

Good location subway was very close felt safe the rooms were very tired and could use some renovations the service was terrible no maid service on weekends front desk was not very pleasent or helpful would

This made an excellent base to introduce our children to NYC. The rooms had an "apartment" feel, which is way better than the hotels in more touristy locations. Admittedly the rooms were a little tired & could do with a bit of redecorating but they were made-up and cleaned daily. Very convenient for subway and buses. A slowly up and coming area that retains a fair bit of what the area was like some years ago - (think kitchen catering renovation businesses....)The staff were happy for us to have a late check-out and also leave our luggage for the day so we could enjoy our last day without having to drag bags aroundGreat value & we'll be retuning for our next visit to NYC.

With the threat looming over airbnb, OSS is a good alternative. I have learned to lower my expectation when I pick an accommodation under USD200 in NYC, but this one more or less feels like a 'home' or a place where I could use as a base while I visit the city. The location is just superb, it's in one block with the Bowery Ballroom, within walking distance with the blooming Nolita, and LES; great cafes, shopping (although scattered). I am fine with 'spartan' hotels and this one puts function above style. The staffs are nice, and quite helpful, and yes Henry Rollins once stayed here...so I would come back someday.

We stayed for a week at the Off Soho Suites. The rooms/bath/kitchen are a little tired, but the location (and the ability to visit Wholefoods up the road to make own meals) completely made up for this.

For me and the family the best place to stay in NYC. Short ways to subway for going sightseeing. Great bars and restaurants close in walking distance for the evening. Super friendly staff and good rooms with everything you need. Special thanks to Gabe.

nothing fancy but I really liked it here. .. most NYC rooms are tiny and this place has lots of roomIt has a kitchen , and a separate bedroom. the windows open for fresh air.there was 3 of us... we got the room with 2 twin beds and a sleeper sofathe sofa was very comfortablelots of good cheap restaurants nearby the only bad thing was the wifi was terrible.. not even usableand we had a street facing room on a lower floor.late at night people in the bar next door would smoke outside right below our room and they were loudbut we were always exhausted from exploring the city all day and even the noise did not keep us upI would definitely stay here again

The economy suite is such a ripoff! The bedroom is sooooo tiny. There is soon for two tiny beds and that's pretty much it. The kitchen didnt have a table nor cleaning instruments. The decor is pretty bad and last we had to share kitchen and bathroom with another couple. Last Internet was basically not working. It was super slow both I'm our room but also in general. For $200 per night it was bad. Next time ill find something on airbnb. The staff was pretty nice though and they were helpful but for the Internet. Location is good. Do not go there.

This was my second stay at the relaxed and no-frills Off Soho Suites. I highly recommend it as an affordable yet clean, quiet, spacious and safe alternative to the plethora of overpriced and cramped hotels at twice the price. Front office staff are alert, friendly and helpful. No shortage of places to eat at and walk to from here. Great water pressure, comfortable beds (even the futon fold out in the living room), A/C worked well. In short, everything you need for a comfortable stay without the frills (and the expense).

Liked: Separate kitchen and living room, close to public transit, clean and stylish suites, helpful staff.Could have been better: Better internet connection, would have liked a TV in the bedroom, and AC was super cold.Overall: would stay again. Loved to walk to everything.

Room 302 a and b. Shared facilities. Worst room ever and i have been to India and China 20 years ago. Chrging $230 a night would not let my dogs sleep here. Tiny room with only 4 coathangers. A chest of drawers fetched from the local dump. Definitely got electricity as wires all over place. I would have expected this in some out of the way town in Africa not New York. Sticking to Europe after this trip

A great deal for multiples and families if you are on a budget. You don't have the luxuries of a concierge, room service, restaurant etc. If you re looking for space, ability to eat in if wanted, this is the place to stay. Three friends on our trip and we had two twins in the bedroom, a full futon in the living room, a kitchen and bath. You are just a couple blocks from Little Italy and Chinatown. We did spend more on cabs as we usually spend a lot of time in Times Square but still came out ahead by a few hundred dollars. Not the best place if you like to do a lot of walking.

The rooms at this serviced apartment are a lot older than what is depicted in the photo's. However for an expensive city such as New York we were willing to overlook the fact that it was quite misrepresented by the photos. However be prepared to have to ask for towels, toilet paper and for rubbish to be taken out an a daily basis. During our two week stay the bed was made only a couple of times, towels were taken and not replaced, or left on the floor, rubbish was left to pile up in bin and we had to consistently ask for replacement toilet paper. Overall the staff are not very friendly and kept accusing us of leaving our do not disturb sign on the door.

If you need space, Off Soho Suites are a good choice. Our room was spacious, large bathroom, full kitchen, sofa area and a separate twin (or queen size?) bed room. This suite easily could accommodate 3 adults with its about 600 sqft. The suite's sleeping room was also quite quiet, once the bar Lorelei downstairs closed its beer garden in the back, which happened after or around midnight. The decor of the hotel and the overall condition of the furniture and fixtures, however, were more worthy of a youth hostel than a hotel! The tiles on the floors of the kitchen and bathroom had numerous cracks and the storage space in the batch room was filthy. To sum up, this hostel needs an urgent revamp (and it is not suspiring that you seem mainly young students / youg hippsters there). What you seen on the pictures on the website does not even come close to what your room will look like.But the service and the gentleman at the reception were very friendly!

This hotel worked out perfectly for a bachelorette party, and easily slept 4 girls in the room. It was one of the very few places I could find that was reasonably affordable, and could comfortably sleep four. The front desk staff were very helpful and the room was comfortable. Highly recommended!

This place is an anomaly. I stayed with family members as we wanted a suite while a relative was in the hospital at NYU (a 15 minute walk up Second Avenue). There is a lot to like here. It is quiet in the evening (except Saturday nights of course). It is near public transportation and an amazing number of excellent inexpensive restaurants, Chinatown, Lower East Side and Soho. Parking is not cheap and the place is decorated and furnished in sparse minimalist decor. But, there is a fully working kitchen to cook, microwave, make coffee, tea. The air-conditioning is effective and the beds are comfortable. It is a lot of square footage for the rate. And if it is hipster vibes or NY charm you want, just head out the front door and walk a few blocks. You could easily fit 4 into the suite with a pull out bed in the living room. Clerk was very helpful when we needed to book on an additional night. If I have two suggestions to the staff. First, we could use a few hooks to hang things in the bedrooms and bathrooms And also, it is great that they have an exercise room, but some of the equipment is not working or working well. The room could use a few more free weights and a fan or two down there would be very, very welcome. Regardless, I will be very happy to go back there for another stay.

I have stayed at the Off Soho Suites on multiple occassions and recommend it to any out of town relatives. This is an apartment-style hotel which features full kitches in each unit, a good location in lower Manhattan, excellent friendly service, and is overall a good value for the price paid. As I mentioned, the location is good, but not exactly central to ALL of the major tourist attractions. However, this is not an issue as NYC is well covered by public transport AND a new bike sharing system called CitiBike which has a pick up location right across the street from the hotel. No issues getting around here!My unit on my most recent stay was #205, a 1 bedroom apartment with a large bathroom (full tub), decent sized bed room and "cozy" but comfortable living room. Of course, this is not a luxury hotel but they don't claim to be. They are a great alternative to cramped hotel rooms of the major chains. Europeans espescially will feel right at home here.Definitely check out this hotel on your next New York adventure.

Stayed at Off Soho Suites for three nights. Great location and excellent value for money given we could comfortably fit three people with two double beds and a sofa bed. Have stayed in a number of different hotels in NYC previously, however, this is one of the best places for value and location (East Village). Only negative is the bathroom which was below standard.

This is such a wonderful place to stay. As a former New Yorker you couldn't find a better location as you are close to the lower east side, Chinatown, Houston St, galleries off Prince and Spring. Huge space too! The people at the front desk were great. Stayed in early March when the price went down.

The location of this hotel is good – it is easy in and out to LaGuardia & JFK Airports via the Williamsburg Bridge. There is a City bike station (shared bicycle system) in the Roosevelt Park across the street. The room was spacious by New York standards. The room also has a full- sized kitchen which I did not use much because I was only staying for 2 nights. And the Wi-Fi in the room was unsteady. Overall the room looked somewhat worn to me.

The location of this place is right in a hip neighborhood where you can find the who's who of the brands present (Gucci, Armani etc). You can find some great places to wine & dine within walking distances. The suites are average and have kitchen if you prefer saving on food cost..

Hotel looks nice till you reach your room that seems to be leprechaun size. The twin room i had shared a bathroom with other room next door. Bathroom was ok - bigger than my room but lots of staff didn't work ( lamp, heardryer etc ). Location is great but still this place is not worth its price.

First let me say that the staff are all very nice and helpful however I would not stay here again. The room was as expected. The kitchen was soooo outdated and the refrigerator was spray painted white even on the inside and was pealing. The dishes, utensils, microwave , toaster were spotless. If the kitchen area and bathrooms were modernized it would be a great place. The lobby was decorated beautiful but that was as far as the decorating went. My room had a smoker previously and I called the front desk and they tried to get the smell out by using a deodorizing spray but all it did was make it worse. Had to put the air conditioner on to try and get rid of the smell but it didnt work and was so cold that I had to sit in a chair for the entire evening with my coat on until I could leave when the sun came up. Everything smelled of smoke. I had a horrible reaction, huge headache and lost my voice few two days. I had to have my coat professionally cleaned and launder everything I took with me that I didn't even wear. Was told to park a few blocks away and I would receive hotel rate but when I picked up my car I was charged $50 and was told that was the hotel rate???? sounds a little fishy to me.

This place looks really cute online but is a bit more scrappy in reality. The location is okay and its affordable considering New York's price levels. But the rooms are not super clean and the ceilings creak from the rooms above. The one bedroom suites are spacious enough however and I didn't mind sleeping in the quiet inner room on the futon sofa. It was actually pretty comfortable. My daughter had more trouble in the bedroom where street noise gave her a restless sleep. I would probably stay there again for the price value but its just average in my mind.

This was my first time going to NYC. It was a trip several of my girlfriends and I took so we looked for a place we could pile up in and split the price. We wanted a place in a decent location that wouldn't break the bank. Off Soho Suites is apartments turned to suites. Unless you were looking for it, you wouldn't even know it was there! It's in between other businesses but it's not an overly busy area. Easy access to lots of eateries, bars, and shopping areas. The suite is very nice. Not too fancy but I never look for fancy. Spacious and clean for the most part. The glasses in the cabinets had some collected dust but that's about it.Overall, it was a very great stay. I will visit NYC again and I'll stay there again!

We got back to the UK this morning from a superb trip to New York, and it's a trip that was very much helped to be fantastic by Off Soho Suites on Rivington St - booked through Expedia it came to about £117 a night, which is as cheap as chips for New York. Yes, it's nothing flash, yes, it could be said to be very slightly shabby, but it's comfortable (really good bed and bed linen), it's quiet (well, room 206 is anyway, towards the back of the hotel), and it's incredibly well situated. We bought groceries from a couple of nearby places and cooked some of our meals in our kitchen (though you're in an area where great places to eat and drink are very thick on the ground), we had tea and coffee making facilities at any time of the day or night, and we also had pretty solid wifi, free. The guys on the front desk were very helpful, the laundry in the basement, while basic, was very handy, and they were more than accommodating about us having stuff delivered to the hotel (man, you can shop in NYC!). We'll be back to New York, hopefully later this year, and we'll definitely be back to Off Soho Suites.

The actual location of this hotel is not great. However, it is within walking distance of some of the nicer areas in the city. The rooms are clean enough, but older. The kitchen has pots and pans but NO utensils?! When we asked, they simply said they did not have any.I have decided that visiting NYC is great if you have lots of money to stay in the nicer hotels.

We stayed in a 2 room suite and it was much larger than I expected! It was basically a one bedroom apartment -- large bathroom, good sized kitchen, spacious bedroom, and eating area / TV watching area where the futon couch / bed are. My husband and I with our two teenage boys found it to be more than comfortable. My sister had the same type room and paid the same price, but hers was a bit smaller -- so you might want to ask for a larger room if available. The front desk staff are very friendly and professional. The kitchen was equipped with dishes and silverware, a skillet, a strainer and a few pots. BRING YOUR OWN COOKING UTENSILS. My sister asked for a larger skillet and they gave her one, but they do not have cooking utensils. Whole Foods is only 2 blocks away, which is great!Our room faced the street, so it was noisy a few times at night -- sirens, honking and "happy" bar patrons exiting the German restaurant next door. This was not a huge problem. I would certainly recommend this hotel to others and I would stay here again.

I spent two nights here with friends in a 4 person suite on the 5th floor. We booked fairly late and got a really good rate via the hotel website. However even at full price between 3 of us it would have been good value by NYC standards. Staff were helpful and pleasant. We had a very spacious kitchen/lounge with queen size futon couch/bed, and twin beds in separate bedroom. The couch cover was a little stained, but otherwise the place was spotless. Beds (including couch) were comfortable, and the bathroom large with a good shower over the tub. Although we didn't make much use of it the kitchen was vast with full size fridge/freezer, stove, and enough basic utensils and crockery for 'proper' cooking. (Tip: bring size 2 filter papers for the coffee machine.)The location was perfect for us. It's not the smartest area of Manhattan and all the better for it in my view. There are good subway connections, bars, and restaurants within a block or two, plus a huge Whole Foods 5 mins away if you're self-catering. The German bar next door was convivial and surprisingly cheap. Pulinos just up Bowery fed us deliciously and amply. The Tenement Museum is 10 mins on foot and well worth a visit. I'd recommend to similar small groups of friends, or families with older kids.

Too close to the Bowery. IF you are a couple looking for an inexpensive place to stay, stay somewhere else! You have to share a bathroom and a fully unequipted kitchen, the size of a closet, and the bedroom has 2 single beds and no room for a dresser. The suites looked better(our friends needed a room for 3), but I'd have preferred to stay in a hotel with a cot than in the "Suite" at Off-Soho. Staff was nice enough but...wouldn't go back and I do not need fancy but this was....just not the place to stay!

Shari S
Toms River, New Jersey

review_body: We stayed here during New Year's week, after staying one night at the Hilton Fashion District in a room that was too small for our family of four. The location is wonderful. We were two blocks from the subway, two blocks from Whole Foods, and right near Little Italy, Chinatown, SoHo, Katz's Deli. Do not expect elegance. What you get is a clean, one bedroom Manhattan apartment with a full kitchen and bathroom. There is a laundry facility downstairs. Do not bother with the fitness room. It is no good. The people who work there are friendly and helpful. There is a great little German beer garden next door. As long as you are okay with staying downtown and doing without a lot of extras, this is the place. We will definitely stay there again.

The staff here are very nice. My friend and I stayed in one room and it was the perfect size for us. The full size kitchen was also nice to have even though we didn't end up using it much. It was awesome being so close to SoHo and even a Whole Foods! Great hotel!!

My family and i went to NYC during December and hotel prices are definitely higher because of the shopping season. It can be difficult to find a place in NYC because there are so many hotels other than your large chain hotels like Hilton/Marriott that you're never quite sure what you could land up with. This place is right in Little Italy not far from Chinatown. The area seemed ok, nothing shady or bad going on. The place when you walk in looks updated. They have some modern decor to spruce the place up. I think this was a converted apartment building. The rooms are nice size, I have stayed at the W Times Square and we were in a shoe box size room. This place had a large bathroom, nice size kitchen and living room and bedroom. If you have kids and need the space i would recommend. The sofa is a futon type sofa that can flatten and be good for kids. It has all the basics and no frills! The TV was maybe 19" flat screen in living room, nothing in bedroom but a bed, closet and alarm clock. The place was clean and I felt safe at night. Water pressure of shower was very strong and hot water gets HOT! I barely turned it on and it was scalding. So beware! Not all rooms are personal bathrooms so read all the details when booking. That goes for anywhere in NYC. I heard they have wifi but could never get it to work. Overall my stay was good and I was not disappointed.

Great location close to subway and easy to get around. The only downside was the heating was too hot that we had to put the zircon on whilst we will out otherwise it was just too hot. Friendly and helpful staff. Nice size suite for three of us with large fridge, oven, coking area. Def recommended

These appear to be all suites with bedroom, living room, and a kitchen. The rooms are furnished like typical NYC apartments, with wood floors and simple kitchens, but the combination of space, location, and price are hard to beat. Check-in was fast and friendly. The location is a bit noisy from traffic in the back.

What better way to experience such a great city than stepping out into funky Soho with great cafes, wonderful restaurants, hip bars, and sensational shopping. Easy access to the subway means the rest of New York is just a few steps away!

penelope r
New York City, New York

review_body: Clean and quiet, friendly staff, and a great location. I didn't need a cab at all. Walking distance to a lot of great shops and places to eat. I will definitely stay here next time I travel to New York City.

Great location, fabulous big suites (I think the bathroom was bigger than some mi town hotels I have stayed in), and good value for money. sadly I won't be able to stay here again as the Internet connection was poor and that is a key thing for me. But definitely recommended for leisure trips to new York.

I'm very impressed! The location, space, and price make it a lot better than staying outside of Manhattan. I highly recommend this hotel. I enjoy coming to New York and next time I will stay here again.

The suites are nice, like apartments with a separate kitchen and living area from the bed room. The staff was very good. The room was clean, the bed was comfortable, and the location in SoHo was excellent.

The positives of this hotel are its ample suites and great location (just around the corner of the New Museum, less than 5 minute walking to 4 different subway stations). WiFi is complimentary and it works pretty well. If you are traveling with a large family, the hotel is well worth it to avoid the ridiculously high room rates in NY for large parties. The building is quite old and common areas are nice and new, but rooms urgently need an update. We had two suites and none of them had air conditioned in the living rooms, only in the bedrooms. This was a nightmare if you are staying there in the summer, so we had to move the sofa beds into the bedrooms (as said before, space is not a constraint). This is a 5 or 6 floor building, hope you are in good shape for the stairs, unless you are willing to spend plenty of your time waiting for the only elevator, since this is relative small and it moves up and down at a speed of approximately 2 inches per second (no kidding!).

algarcia78
New York City, New York

review_body: I spent a few nights at Off Soho Suites and it was very comfortable and located in a convenient area for walking to many places. I also had a kitchen in my room, which made my trip cheaper because I didn't have to go out for food.

If you need extra room, this hotel with suites is a very rare find in NYC. We only stayed one night but found the front desk attendants to be very friendly and helpful. Yes, the kitchen cabinets were very worn and in need of updating (do they know you can make a difference just by refacing???). However, the bathroom was a good size and clean. Bedroom too was a bit bigger than your average NY room. Couch is a futon, but not so sure it would be comfortable to sleep on. Kids may not mind it so much. I do wish they had black out draperies - morning sun was very bright in the room. Also, try to get a room away from the beer garden next door (not an issue in winter). All in all a comfortable stay and a great base for exploring the Lower East Side, Little Italy and Chinatown.
We spent 2 nites in Off Soho Suites in June and it is reasonably good in terms of location but the room needs to have a paint and clean up job.
Had to stay in the hotel for a day, but the service offered was poor. we had to go to the reception to get the things we needed, like extra towels etc. Otherwise the overall stay was quite good.

I went to NYC for a few nights to visit some friends, and decided to stay at the Off Soho Suites. It was perfect and I appreciate that it was well located and still has some of the feel of the village in the old days.
Great location and service. Everyone that I came in contact with was very kind and helpful. When I come back to the city I will make a reservation with Off Soho!
Just stayed here for the second time this month. The rooms are great an of an ample size, IT is close to just about everything. I would recommend bringing or buying your own coffee for the morning.

We enjoyed the extra space of the suite and having a kitchen allowed us to save a bit of money since we were able to get pastries and fresh squeezed orange juice from Whole Foods right around the corner. This place is a value for families since squabbling kids (not mine!) can have separate spaces. The suites have been partially redone to give it a "loft" feel. But room are also a bit worn, especially the kitchen. But, hey, it's NYC and we were out most of the time in places like the East Village and Soho, both of which are quite close.So if you lower your expectations a bit, you might see why I rated this "very good," although somewhere between the Trip Advisor categories of "average" and "very good" would be a better fit. We've stayed in other hotels in NYC and paid a lot more. But to tell the truth, those hotels can seem a bit precious and overrated. So we went for an underrated place and we're okay with that choice because of the extra room.
This is a great hotel. Its location is reasonably close to the subway (a couple stops to Fulton, etc). The room was a decent size and clean. There are plenty of eateries and fun bars nearby.

We checked in late and just needed a locked room with a bed and bathroom - with reasonable expectations of what was possible in NYC - and didn't quite get that. Room hadn't been cleaned - mystery red substance we're hoping was nail polish by the closet floor, damp towels thrown on the beds, and make up all over the pillowcase and sheets. Pulled the old coverlet over the bed and called it a night with sounds of boho charm below (actually more charming than the "hotel") - then woke up to a cold shower. Left as early as we booked late and I'm guessing manager made assumptions about "spoiled Americans" as he made a philosophical remark like "Hey, that's travel" - I've been to multiple countries and stayed at places in various budget ranges and while the privacy makes this more than a hostel, the lack of sanitation makes it worse. Lots of comments here point to same ... So start listening! Won't be back, especially with cleaner, cheaper options in same area and all around if planned/planning ahead (Hotwire!). Agree with previous poster, Henry Rollins and Slash might have stayed here in their up-and-coming gigging days - but none of that makes this cool. Their standards have been raised and so have mine.

Stayed here for 6 nights last month and couldn't have asked for more at such a reasonable price. Let me start by saying that I've been to NYC many, many times and have always stayed in Times Square/Theatre District at places like Marriott Marquis, the W, etc. This is completely different but for a third of the price and to be closer to Soho and Greenwich, etc., it was perfect. My daughter and I stayed in a twin suite and I could see that the single rooms would have been quite a tight fit, but our suite was absolutely perfect. Full kitchen, sitting area with couch, nice sized bathroom and a separate bedroom with twin beds. Front desk staff were extremely helpful and unfailingly polite. They helped us with advice, hiring a private car service, with luggage, adding a night, etc. etc. Also recommend trying the German bar/restaurant next door-- doesn't look like much from the outside, but inside it's a family-friendly bar with interesting food and tons of great beer choices. Our room was also equipped with a coffee maker, microwave, dishes, etc. etc. and an AC unit in the living area. There's an elevator. Nothing is exactly "plush" but it's more than adequate (and I'm a pretty picky customer). My only slight complaint is that the WIFI is spotty at times (and you can go down to the lounge to get a stronger signal, I believe). Overall, I'd stay here again and would recommend it as an economical solution!

very good value + we enjoyed and will come back + recommend it, great location, friendly servicevery good value + we enjoyed and will come back + recommend itvery good value + we enjoyed and will come back + recommend it

We booked here so we had the option of preparing a bit of food for ourselves to save money and with the Whole Foods Market just two blocks away that worked very well. Our suite was roomy and comfortable and the reception was really helpful. We had some trouble with our safe and they sent someone up immediately to fix it.The location was great, easy for bus or metro, and within walking distance of lots of great stuff.

We stayed a full week in New York City at the Off Soho Suites. They we generous enough to let us check in at 10:30 and the rooms are massive, comfortable, reasonably tidy (although the floor was a little sticky) and have a full kitchen - if you can be bothered cooking... Its a short stroll to the Italian and Chinese quarters where you can get a good feed for a reasonably small outlay.Its a great walk through Hudson Square up to Meat Packing where you can jump on the Highline - this is the best part of NYC! What a fantastic initiative and all should be commended on its development.Soho is very authentic and lacks the glitz and glam of Times Square; but we're not much into that anyway. The daily rubbish collection is a little confronting at first, but that's how this massive city functions. Good times.

It is not luxury, but its not a dump either. If you want decent sleep and not spent all your money on a room, this is the perfect spot. The location is really awesome, the reception and their service is AMAZING, they will do anything for you. Next time i come to NY, i will stay at this place again.

We booked Off Soho because there were three of us and the suite layout really worked and allowed us to save significantly over booking two regular rooms elsewhere. The location was great, the hotel very clean and the street noise was surprisingly low. Unfortunately, the same can't be said for the noise inside the hotel. Paper thin walls and ceilings allowed us to hear every move of our neighbors - especially the guest directly above us who we imagined must have been having late night dancing lessons. If you're a heavy sleeper or hard of hearing, this place would be ideal, though. But it is true not to expect too much service - it's pretty low key, but there IS housekeeping service and the Wifi did work fine in our room. Note that the check out time is apparently 11 am, even though the outdated binder in our room stated it was at noon. I think this place would be especially good for longer stays where a kitchen is required. Due to the noise, I probably won't stay again myself, but I wouldn't not recommend it (with the noise caveat, of course).

Just returned from a 1 week stay with my daughter and granddaughter. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay here. The staff was excellent - very friendly and helpful. Housekeeping was in every day and did a great job. I am a clean freak and had no problem with the condition of the suite The kitchen area was great, large fridge, stove, microwave, toaster and coffee maker. Cabinets and drawers were clean and neat. While the rooms are slightly worn the furniture was in great condition and the beds were comfortable. The suite is big with a large closet in the bedroom and storage shelves in the bathroom. Lots of room to stretch out! So much better than a cramped hotel room. There is also a great sitting area on the main floor.The location was good - subway "F" line is 2 blocks away. We all felt very safe here, there are lots of people out and about in this area all the time. The Whole Foods store is right by the subway stop so picking up food is easy. Chinatown and Little Italy are a very short walk and there is a cute cupcake place about 10 mins away.I would definitely recommend Off Soho Suites and will use it for future trips to NYC.

We're just back from a week over new year and stayed here, plus points are- location so near little Italy and Chinatown, great subway "F" line only 5 mins walk, friendly and helpful staff, having so much more space than a hotel room. Downside is that some parts of our accom were a bit run down ie missing tiles in bathroom and marks on walls. Overall i think it is great value 4 money. I've a great tip if you plan to spend new year, book really early as we booked in march 2011 and got the same rate for each night. When we arrived they couldn't believe we hadn't been charged the correct rate for 30 and 31 dec, which was $995 and we had paid less than $300. Try grotta assura on mulberry street, fantastic food.

We arrived late at night and were directed up to our appartment supposedly for four. The kids shared a twin room whilst myself and my husband got busy trying to sort out the sofa bed in the living area. It was small and hard to put up and the sparse bedding for it made it very unwelcoming. We had three nights here and I wouldn't recommend it, however it was cheap compared to anywhere else we found.
Couldn't believe such spacious, apartment style accommodation could be found in such a cool location in New York

I will give you a decent perspective on this hotel. I like it - didn't love it. My wife hated it.. We both love the location. We stayed here as the price was right. The suites are not much different from the one bedroom aprtments our friends had in Manhattan just after college. Unfortunately, we have grown beyond that.  Cleanme: YesWife: yesSpaciousme: yeswife: yesRoom in good conditionme: It's ok but getting a bit long in the tooth. Wife: Totally unacceptable. Cheap furniture when new. Even worse now. Homey:me: not really - but serviceablewife: Awful - uncomfortable - for all the room, not enough comfortable furniture to sit on. Location:me: Great - love Little Italy and SohoWife: SameBottom line: - Do not expect miracles here. You are not paying for them. If I had this apartment fresh out of college, I'd have been happy. However, college was a while back and my wife and I have come to expect more. I would return to this hotel as the location is so amazing that it more than makes up for the only fair but clean rooms. However, I will not be returning except perhaps for the occasional guys weekend, as my wife will not.

We had the 2 beds only room -- it was about 8 X 8, with 12 inches between the beds and double that at the foot of the beds. Two people could stand in the room, but just barely. The window air conditioner was ancient, with a broken grill, missing knobs, etc. It was not a pleasant place. The kitchen was the lowest grade, junkiest stuff you could imagine. No coffee maker, no clock in the roomBathroom was reasonable, a decent size, and the lobby was OK too. The closest of the two subway stops was on a line that pretty much went only to Brooklyn and the financial district and the other (Grand Street. ) was more useful, but several blocks away. The neighborhood is fascinating: chic galleries next to bombed out bodegas. Its a walk to anywhere, but if youlike walking (I don't) great neighborhood to be in.

Stayed here in early October 2011 for three nights. The good: If you love the LES and Soho (I do), this is a great location. My wife and I stayed in a studio suite (which can accommodate up to 4), so with the kitchen and separate bedroom the stay was more like apartment than hotel living. Whole Foods is two short blocks away, making it very convenient to stock up for use of the kitchen. We booked far enough in advance to obtain a reasonable rate for this time of year.The not-so-good: You'll have to order out for service and hospitality. They were friendly enough whenever we went in and out, but whenever we had a request, we were reminded that they keep their costs down by not investing in hospitality training. We arrived shortly after 8 a.m. to check in and were immediately informed that check-in was at 3 p.m., but they could hold our bags. I asked them to please check the reservation: we had anticipated this, and had reserved an extra night, so we could have our room upon arriving after our overnight flight. They quickly recanted, but this was just the beginning of an attitude that begins with "the customer doesn't know what he/she is doing," After day one, we returned to find that neither my wife, nor my card key worked. We were admonished to keep the room keys away from our credit cards. Once again, the customer is suspect; they couldn't possibly have keyed two cards incorrectly, but both my wife and I carelessly demagnetized the room cards. We were further reprimanded for leaving the privacy sign on our door all day, which prevented us from receiving towel service that day. (I was under the impression that there were no automatic services, so I didn't think to remove the sign when we left for the day.Finally, when we requested a 1 p.m. check out, we received the automatic response that they were fully booked, and that check out time is noon - and that we should be happy with that, because 11 a.m. is the customary check out time. I reminded the attendant that we paid a full extra night, in order to check in at 8 a.m., and questioned whether asking for an extra hour on a four night stay was unreasonable - but he was not impressed. However, he graciously gave us the extra hour. The bottom line:If you get a good rate and want to indulge in the fantasy of living in an apartment on the border of LES/Soho with a grumpy landlord, then this is the place to book your experience. If you expect service with a smile, then this should not be on your list of alternative abodes.I am giving them a good review, because they don't even pretend to be service oriented, so expectations should not be high.

Having read other reviews on this website after booking the hotel I was unsure about staying here but very pleasently surprised! The rooms and small but very comfortable - if you are out all day all you need in somewhere to sleep! Self contained so we could eat breakfast at home before leaving for the day. The staff were VERY friendly and helpful which was fantastic. And the location is perfect - 5min walk from subway stations, $15 cab ride to central park and surrounding by fabulous shopping and eating in soho and little Italy! Would definitely stay here again!

So a group of four of us stayed here in the off season. The room was really nice! Full kitchen with dishes, fridge, big tv with a couch. The lobby was pretty. The location was great for Lower East Side lovers (like us) and the price was great! We got half off a four-person suite because it was November. Now for the not-so-great: Parking is down the street and around the corner, but you get a discount voucher from the hotel. Two of the four beds are real beds in the bedroom, the other two are a super uncomfortable fold out futon. Really hard and kind of old and gross. You have to pay extra for "maid service" so no one took away our kitchen garbage for three days and by the third day it was disgusting. And we overheard a nasty fight between the hotel clerk/manager and two guests because he would not honor the discount they thought they were getting.But all in all, it's the best for your buck in the LSE. I would stay again if I got the 50% discount again. Those suites are not worth $300-$400 a night.

Our family enjoyed our stay at Off Soho. The suite was clean and roomy enough for four adults. The staff was exceptionally friendly,pleasant and helpful. The hotel was convenient to Chinatown, Little Italy,Soho and St. Marks place and an easy subway ride to other areas of the city. My only "complaint" was the mattress on the pull out sofa bed. This was a bit thin and lumpy and could use an upgrade. The kitchenette could have used a coffeemaker too.
on a vibrant street in a colourful but pretty safe area. Nice and clean. large apartment. Air con pretty noisy but you could sleep through it. Lovely bathroom.

CHARACTER, CHARACTER, CHARACTER. Upon arriving at OFF SOHO, after a very long flight, I was greeted by a very warm receptionist. The suite was huge, immaculate, and very comfortable. The location is to die for and within walking distance to everything. I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone who wishes to experience a true New York boutique hotel.

I stayed here for four nights at the end of a warm October 2010 together with three of my friends. We needed an affordable and comfortable place to sleep in Manhattan and we found it. Our room was big (2 single beds in one room, one sofa bed in a comfortably large living room/kitchen area) and got cleaned every day. The bedroom was on the street side, and right across the hotel is some kind of depot, so around 5 or 6 am there was a bit of noise. There was airco in the room, which was most welcome in this warm October week. We never ate in, although everything we needed was in the room: The hotel is perfectly located in the best part of manhattan: right off prince and spring, with lots of restaurants, cafes and bars nearby. chinatown and litte italy are very close as well and broadway of course, which makes for a perfect location for shopping!i would return here again for the location and the comfort of the room. It might be a bit expensive though if you can't divide the room price by four but either way, this location and this kind of money...it's hard to find

This was the cheapest we could find for one night and pictures reflected it to look somewhat contemporary/modern. It was clean, but in need of a major overhaul. Hardwood floors very old, needed to be refinished, bathroom needed to be gutted. Just old and needed TLC. No central air. Window air conditioner. Cute fun German bar next door. Walking distance of Chinatown/Little Italy.Parking on Elizabeth Street, but make sure you get your ticket validated or they won't honor hotel discount for parking. Front desk staff very accommodating and welcoming.

Endicott, New York

review_body: As many other reviews pointed out, the expectation before arrival is a nice cheap hotel in a decent area. We arrived on a sketchy small street with an out of place hotel right across from a run down warehouse. DO NOT GO TO THIS HOTEL. The relative (It really isn't ) cheaper hotel cost really isn't worth it. The clerk is rude and always make excuses about not giving you the service you ask for, and is overall an unhelpful person. The hotel has nice pictures in their websites, but be warned, those clearly doesn't accurately reflect what the rooms are and the quality of it.

We stayed one night at Off Soho Suites, with our three kids, ages 5, 12 and 16. We were given a dank room on the ground floor, with the excuse that the extra bed we'd ordered could not be delivered to an upper floor. Perhaps rooms on higher floors are nicer, but I will never go back to find out.The entire place felt run-down and un-cared-for. Ceiling fixtures hung from rough, un-patched holes in the sheetrock. Our room was dirty - floors had a residue of dirt and dust that ruled out walking barefoot. Let's just say the bathroom was not a place one wanted to linger. When you don't even want to touch the toiletries provided, you know there's something wrong.The final straw was finding ants in the bed when I woke up. Including the extra bed charge and taxes, this room came to over $400 a night. What a rip-off.(I should add that I'm a transplanted native New Yorker, who has traveled extensively to NYC on business, and so I don't have unrealistic expectations for NY hotels or the city in general. Aside from it's good location, this hotel is not worth it.)

I'm reluctant to write a review for this hotel, because I'm worried that if too many people find out about it, it might never be available. I've stayed here twice in the last year and would go back time after time. The location is perfect for exploring the shops in Soho and the bars and cafes in Nolita. We arrived early on the day of the blizzard, after 30hrs of travel (and our luggage being lost), and staff helped us out by giving us a room straight away. We were very grateful.

In past trips overseas we have stayed in all levels of accomodation (incl Sofitel Washington/ Bellagio Vegas on this trip also). NYC accomodation is very expensive, and we were under no illusions we would be getting what we paid for, though were really happy that our expectation was exceeded. We knew before we arrived that the NYC experience would be about cramming as much into our day as we could - and crashing when we got to bed - to us, the room was somewhere to put our head down. The trade off, is the money we could save in accommodaiton we could put into expereinces in the City.The Rivington streetscape is a bit edgy, though once through the door, we were greeted with the friendliest desk manager we have ever encountered - Gabe is a deadset legend - one of the lovliest blokes we have encountered, and every night gave us the opportunity to shoot the breeze with a hard working family man.Location wise, the place is brilliant - a short walk to the Bowery, where the only decent cup of espresso coffee in NY seems to be made (head to Think Coffee). Close to Chinatown/ Little Italty/ Soho/ East Village - in short, a walk in any direction gets you to an interesting part of the city. The 2nd Ave subway uptown is a short walk around the block, and Prince St on the Yellow Line (a bit further west of Broadway) opens up a heap of other options. Try Cup and Saucer for a US diner brekkie experience and Prosperity Dumplings for authentic Chinese at a ridiculously low price. (both on Eldridge St) If you are after glitz, and are willing to pay for the honour, head mid/ uptown. If you want a really central location that allows you the opportunity to spend the extra $'s saved from an uptown chain hotel, this is the digs.

When we first drove down Rivington Street we all were a little concerned with what was awaiting us, especially myself who booked the accommodation for me and two friends (one male, one female) to celebrate my 30th. However, Rivington Street is a loooong street and the suites are at the nicer end. We arrived on Thanksgiving and were pleased to see a friendly face behind reception. This set the standard of the service throughout our five night stay, not at all intrusive, very relaxed but more than happy to offer advice and help when needed. Our room was on the 2nd floor, very clean, comfortable and big enough for three. The only thing it could of benefitted from was more storage for clothing, there were not enough hangers and we all ended up living out of our suitcases. The room was incredibly warm and cosy which was welcomed after the coldness of the days out, just remember that when you are putting on the layers!! We had no problems celebrating my birthday with a few friends from NYC in the room before heading out. They had storage for baggage on our last day which was most useful. The area immediatly around the accommodation is not an indication of what is on offer nearby so dont be put off, what looks like bordered up and closed shops all came alive after the thanksgiving break and we were across the road from the cool and quirky designer area of Soho, a 10 min walk from Little Italy and a nice 5-10 min walk from the nearest subway for access to uptown and downtown. Once we got our bearings we felt really comfortable, safe and happy with our choice o accommodation. Take time to look into local shops and eateries, and Broadway East is all but a 10 min walk with highstreet shops, bars and restaurants! Thoroughly enjoyed our stay, simple accommodation but safe, welcoming and great value.
